related.Code: "Optimistic locking exception during job acquisition. If you have multiple job executors running against the same database, " + "this exception means that this thread tried to acquire a job, which already was acquired by another job executor acquisition thread." + "This is expected behavior in a clustered environment. "+ "You can ignore this message if you indeed have multiple job executor acquisition threads running against the same database. "+ "Exception message: {}"

"+ "You can ignore this message if you indeed have multiple job executor acquisition threads running against the same database. "+ "Exception message: {}",optimisticLockingException.getMessage())

notRelated.Code: Called by the job executor when a new job was added by the
process engine to which this job executor belongs.
This is a hint, that for example the acquiring needs to start again

* Called by the job executor when a new job was added by the  process engine to which this job executor belongs.  This is a hint, that for example the acquiring needs to start again  when it would be sleeping.
* Called when the job executor is shutting down and the job acquiring needs to be shut down too.
Called when the job executor is shutting down and the job
acquiring needs to be shut down too.

/** 
 * @author Tom Baeyens

 * @author Joram Barrez
 */
* Called when a new job was added by the process engine to which this job executor belongs. This is a hint, that for example the acquiring needs to start again when it would be sleeping.
* Shuts down the whole job executor
* Possibility to ensure everything is nicely initialized before starting the threads
Called when a new job was added by the process engine to which
this job executor belongs. This is a hint, that for example
the acquiring needs to start again when it would be sleeping.
Shuts down the whole job executor

/** *

Interface to the work management component of activiti.

This component is responsible for performing all background work ( {@link Job Jobs}) scheduled by activiti.

You should generally only have one of these per Activiti instance (process engine) in a JVM. In clustered situations, you can have multiple of these running against the same queue + pending job list.

* @author Daniel Meyer * @author Joram Barrez */
Possibility to ensure everything is nicely initialized before starting the threads
log.info("job acquisition thread sleeping for {} millis",millisToWait)
The job executor. Only works with the
* Flag to indicate a job was added (used when the runnable was sleeping, but a job was created by the engine)
Flag to indicate whether the runnable is currently waiting.
* Flag to indicate whether the runnable is currently waiting.
Flag to indicate the runnable was interrupted
Flag to indicate a job was added (used when the runnable was sleeping, but a job was created by the engine)
* The job executor. Only works with the  {@link LockFreeJobExecutor} implementation
of 'acquiring' jobs, which means setting the current job executor
name into the lock owner colum to 'acquire' it.
Later on, these jobs will be fetched and put on the work queue.

/** 
 * {@link AcquireJobsRunnable} implementation with sole purposeof 'acquiring' jobs, which means setting the current job executor name into the lock owner colum to 'acquire' it. Later on, these jobs will be fetched and put on the work queue.
 * @author jbarrez
 */
* Flag to indicate the runnable was interrupted
* The maximum number of threads that are kept alive in the threadpool for job execution
* The time (in seconds) that is waited to gracefully shut down the threadpool used for job execution
* The runnable responsible for fetching the jobs and put on the queue
When a job is removed from the currentlyProcessedJobs (in the ExecuteJobsRunnable), there can be a
slight window of overlap: the jobs are already fetched in memory, but the removal happened just before.
At that point, the acquirement logic will try to put them on the queue again
(because they were read from the database AND not found in the 'currentlyProcessedJobs' set,
hence they are thought to be real, unprocessed jobs).
To solve this, we keep a LRU cache of the last deleted entries.
The size of this cache is equal to the 'currentlyProcessedJobs' size or the jobFetchBatchSize
(the largest one of the two). Making it larger has no point, as with this
size the window of overlap is covered
The maximum number of threads that are kept alive in the threadpool for job execution
* The queue used for job execution work
The time (in milliseconds) a thread used for job execution must be kept alive before it is
destroyed. Default setting is 0. Having a non-default setting of 0 takes resources,
but in the case of many job executions it avoids creating new threads all the time.
* The minimal number of threads that are kept alive in the threadpool for job execution
The number of jobs fetched in one query after they are already acquired
* The size of the queue on which jobs to be executed are placed
The runnable responsible for fetching the jobs and put on the queue

/** 
 * JobExecutor, the next generation.
 * @author Joram Barrez
 */
The time (in seconds) that is waited to gracefully shut down the threadpool used for job execution
The minimal number of threads that are kept alive in the threadpool for job execution
The thread pool used for job execution
log.info("Creating thread pool queue of size {}",queueSize)
log.warn("Timeout during shutdown of job executor. " + "The current running jobs could not end within " + secondsToWaitOnShutdown + " seconds after shutdown operation.")
* The thread pool used for job execution
* The number of jobs fetched in one query after they are already acquired
* Used to avoid putting the same job twice on the queue
The queue used for job execution work
The size of the queue on which jobs to be executed are placed
Used to avoid putting the same job twice on the queue

* The time (in milliseconds) a thread used for job execution must be kept alive before it is destroyed. Default setting is 0. Having a non-default setting of 0 takes resources, but in the case of many job executions it avoids creating new threads all the time.
log.warn("Interrupted while shutting down the job executor. ",e)

* When a job is removed from the currentlyProcessedJobs (in the ExecuteJobsRunnable), there can be a  slight window of overlap: the jobs are already fetched in memory, but the removal happened just before. At that point, the acquirement logic will try to put them on the queue again  (because they were read from the database AND not found in the 'currentlyProcessedJobs' set, hence they are thought to be real, unprocessed jobs). To solve this, we keep a LRU cache of the last deleted entries.  The size of this cache is equal to the 'currentlyProcessedJobs' size or the jobFetchBatchSize (the largest one of the two). Making it larger has no point, as with this  size the window of overlap is covered
